markdownRemark.html:
There’s nothing that can make you feel quite as stupid as not knowing a language– even when you are simply using a toilet. Yes, in a lot of countries it is common to communicate in English while traveling and we do it with a sense of security. But, in my personal experience, not having at least some knowledge of the local language is truly limiting.

Here are a couple of sentences that will come in handy getting by everyday in Spain:

Greetings

  • Hola – “hi” or “hello.”
  • Buenos días – “good morning”
  • Buenas tardes – “good afternoon”
  • Buenas noches – “goodnight”
  • ¿Cómo está usted? – the formal way to ask how someone is doing, and is appropriate to use with people older than you, superiors at work or school, or even with strangers on the street.
  • ¿Cómo estás? – an informal way to ask the same question. You can use this phrase when speaking with friends, co-workers, or family
  • ¿Qué tal? – casual way to ask how someone is doing, similar to the phrase “What’s up?” in English.

Pardons

  • Con permiso – “excuse me”
  • Disculpe – politely way to get someone,s attention.
  • Perdón – apologizing for something you’ve done—bumping into someone, for example.

Asking for directions

  • ¿Dónde está…? – “Where is…?” Then it’s up to you to fill in the blank!
  • ¿Dónde está mi hotel? – how to find your way to your hotel.
  • ¿Dónde hay un banco? – If you’re looking for a nearby bank.
  • ¿Dónde hay un cajero automático? – if you only need an ATM machine, you go for this question instead.
  • ¿Dónde hay un restaurante? – how to ask for a restaurant.
  • ¿Dónde hay un hospital? – how yo ask for a hospital.
  • ¿Dónde puedo encontrar…? – “Where can I find…?”
  • ¿Dónde puedo encontrar un taxi? – How to ask for a taxi.
  • ¿Dónde puedo encontrar a un policía? – the way to find a policeman.

Eating out

  • Tengo una reservación. – “I have a reservation,”
  • De tomar, quiero/quisiera… – “To drink, I would like…”
  • De entrada, quiero/quisiera… – “For my appetizer, I would like…”
  • Como plato principal, quiero/quisiera… – “As a main course, I would like…”
  • Yo soy vegeterano- “I’m vegetarian”
  • No como… – “I don’t eat…”
  • ¡Salud! – “cheers”

Shopping

  • ¿Puedo probarme…? – “can I try on....
  • ¿Hasta qué hora está? - “Until what time are you open?”
  • ¿Qué precio tiene…? – “What is the price?”
  • ¿Es el mejor precio que me da? - “Is that the best price you can do?”
  • Puedo darle… – “I can give you,” to offer a price on an item.

Asking for help

  • Necesito ayuda. – Short and to the point, this phrase simply means “I need help.”
  • ¿Usted habla inglés? – Use this phrase to ask if someone speaks English.
  • ¿Dónde puedo encontrar a alguien que hable inglés? – “Where can I find someone who speaks English?”

Thank you and goodbye

  • Gracias – You probably already knew how to say “thank you” in Spanish, but this is just a quick reminder that politeness is appreciated even more in Hispanic and Latino cultures. Say it, and say it a lot!
  • Adiós – “goodbye.”
  • Hasta luego – “see you later.”
  • Hasta mañana – “See you tomorrow,”
  • Nos vemos – “See you”

Have you ever had an interesting experience because of language barriers in Spain? If so, we’d love to hear from you.

frontmatter.title: A few essential Spanish phrases to help you survive the first few months of moving to Spain
frontmatter.description: Making the choice of schools when moving to Spain can be tricky. Here we give you some guidance through the choices based on our experience
frontmatter.author: Mariska Grobler

frontmatter.title: Crocodile Park
frontmatter.description: Crocodile Park - The Crocodile Park is home to more than 200 crocodiles. Visits include a guided tour and live demonstrations.
tags: Top things to do in Costa del Sol

node.html: The Crocodile Park is home to more than 200 crocodiles. Visits include a guided tour and live demonstrations.

frontmatter.title: Costa Jump Marbella
frontmatter.description: Costa Jump Marbella - A trampoline park offering an enormous indoor arena filled with 50 interconnected wall to wall trampolines. There are also sister parks in Seville and Granada.
tags: Top things to do in Andalusia when it rains

node.html: A trampoline park offering an enormous indoor arena filled with 50 interconnected wall to wall trampolines. There are also sister parks in Seville and Granada.

frontmatter.title: Quadbike safari costa del sol
frontmatter.description: Quadbike safari costa del sol - Take an adventure in an off-road buggy and experience the breathtaking Andalusian countryside.
tags: Top things to do in Costa del Sol

node.html: Take an adventure in an off-road buggy and experience the breathtaking Andalusian countryside.

frontmatter.title: Fuengirola Adventure Golf
frontmatter.description: Fuengirola Adventure Golf - Lots of courses to play and some very tricky ones. There is also a good snack bar available.
tags: Top things to do in Costa del Sol

node.html: Lots of courses to play and some very tricky ones. There is also a good snack bar available.

frontmatter.title: Cines Teatro Goya
frontmatter.description: Cines Teatro Goya - Cinema showing the latest released movies in English.
tags: Top things to do in Andalusia when it rains

node.html: Cinema showing the latest released movies in English.

frontmatter.title: Mijas Feria (September)
frontmatter.description: Mijas Feria (September) - During the spring and summer months, many of the local towns and cities celebrate their local ‘ferias’ (fairs). Lasting anything from 5 days to 10 days, they all feature fun fairs in the evenings with lots of rides and activities for all the family
tags: Top things to do in Costa del Sol

node.html: During the spring and summer months, many of the local towns and cities celebrate their local ‘ferias’ (fairs). Lasting anything from 5 days to 10 days, they all feature fun fairs in the evenings with lots of rides and activities for all the family

frontmatter.title: Centre Georges Pompidou Málaga
frontmatter.description: Centre Georges Pompidou Málaga - The Pompidou de Málaga is located at the end of the promenade. A museum of contemporary art well thought out and with some very remarkable works of art. k
tags: Top things to do in Malaga

node.html: The Pompidou de Málaga is located at the end of the promenade. A museum of contemporary art well thought out and with some very remarkable works of art.

frontmatter.title: Museo de Artes y Costumbres Populares de Sevilla
frontmatter.description: Museo de Artes y Costumbres Populares de Sevilla - Located in the center of María Luisa Park, in Plaza de América. The Museum houses a unique collection of objects used in traditional crafts, as well as everyday objects of family life. .
tags: Top Free Things to do with Kids in Andalusia

node.html: Located in the center of María Luisa Park, in Plaza de América. The Museum houses a unique collection of objects used in traditional crafts, as well as everyday objects of family life.

frontmatter.title: Monday - Marbella steet market
frontmatter.description: Monday - Marbella steet market - This market has 350+ stalls that sells fruit, vegetables, clothing, toys and locally-made arts and crafts..
tags: Top Free Things to do with Kids in Andalusia

node.html: This market has 350+ stalls that sells fruit, vegetables, clothing, toys and locally-made arts and crafts.

frontmatter.title: Friday Benalmadena street market
frontmatter.description: Friday Benalmadena street market - The Friday market at Tivoli is large and very busy. You will find anything you are looking for, including clothes, fruit and vegetables, etc.
tags: Top Free Things to do with Kids in Andalusia

node.html: The Friday market at Tivoli is large and very busy. You will find anything you are looking for, including clothes, fruit and vegetables, etc.

frontmatter.title: Sunday - Coin - Organic Market
frontmatter.description: Sunday - Coin - Organic Market - This market is situated beside La Trocha shopping centre to the north of the town centre and sells organic fruit and vegetables.
tags: Top Free Things to do with Kids in Andalusia

node.html: This market is situated beside La Trocha shopping centre to the north of the town centre and sells organic fruit and vegetables.

frontmatter.title: Thursday- Torremolinos street market
frontmatter.description: Thursday- Torremolinos street market - The market is in the Sports/Cultural area behind the Town Hall. Mostly sells clothes, underwear, and some Moroccan leather goods.
tags: Top Free Things to do with Kids in Andalusia

node.html: The market is in the Sports/Cultural area behind the Town Hall. Mostly sells clothes, underwear, and some Moroccan leather goods.

frontmatter.title: Real Alcazar Seville
frontmatter.description: Real Alcazar Seville - This monument were declared as a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1987 and represents the historical evolution of the city of Seville in the last millennium. Influences by different cultures is highly noticeable starting from the Arabic period, late Middle Ages Mudéjar right through to the Renaissance, Baroque and the XIX century.
tags: Top things to do in Seville

node.html: This monument were declared as a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1987 and represents the historical evolution of the city of Seville in the last millennium. Influences by different cultures is highly noticeable starting from the Arabic period, late Middle Ages Mudéjar right through to the Renaissance, Baroque and the XIX century.

frontmatter.title: Alcazaba
frontmatter.description: Alcazaba - This fortress palace whose name in Arabic means citadel is one of the historical monuments of the city, a space visited for combining history and beauty in the same place. Its military component makes it one of the most important Muslim works preserved in Spain.
tags: Top things to do in Malaga

node.html: This fortress palace whose name in Arabic means citadel is one of the historical monuments of the city, a space visited for combining history and beauty in the same place. Its military component makes it one of the most important Muslim works preserved in Spain.

frontmatter.title: Castillo de Gibralfaro
frontmatter.description: Castillo de Gibralfaro - Located next to the historic center on top of a hill next to the Alcazaba in a superb watchtower on the Mediterranean. The Castle of Gibralfaro has a Phoenician origin when it was a lighthouse that stood on a hill called Gibralfaro, later the Arabs reconverted it into a fortress that, later, would be modified to become Alcázar.
tags: Top things to do in Malaga

node.html: Located next to the historic center on top of a hill next to the Alcazaba in a superb watchtower on the Mediterranean. The Castle of Gibralfaro has a Phoenician origin when it was a lighthouse that stood on a hill called Gibralfaro, later the Arabs reconverted it into a fortress that, later, would be modified to become Alcázar.

frontmatter.title: Metropol Parasol
frontmatter.description: Metropol Parasol - Las Setas de Sevilla , also known as the Metropol Parasol project by the architect Jürgen Mayer, is the largest wooden structure in the world and its construction was carried out with the aim of renovating the Plaza de la Encarnación in the city of Seville.
tags: Top things to do in Seville

node.html: Las Setas de Sevilla , also known as the Metropol Parasol project by the architect Jürgen Mayer, is the largest wooden structure in the world and its construction was carried out with the aim of renovating the Plaza de la Encarnación in the city of Seville.

frontmatter.title: Museo Ruso
frontmatter.description: Museo Ruso - The Russian Museum Collection Center St. Petersburg Malaga is a seat of the Russian State Museum located in the former Royal Tobacco Factory in Malaga. Next to the exhibition halls, the center has an auditorium, three screening rooms, children's workshops, reading room with reference books, a virtual museum headquarters, cafeteria and shop.
tags: Top things to do in Malaga

node.html: The Russian Museum Collection Center St. Petersburg Malaga is a seat of the Russian State Museum located in the former Royal Tobacco Factory in Malaga. Next to the exhibition halls, the center has an auditorium, three screening rooms, children's workshops, reading room with reference books, a virtual museum headquarters, cafeteria and shop.

frontmatter.title: Bullring Ronda
frontmatter.description: Bullring Ronda - Although not the largest by capacity, Plaza de Toros is the largest ring in Spain, and possibly the world. Even if you disapprove of bullfighting this is a great tour for the history and the architecture.
tags: Top things to do in Malaga

node.html: Although not the largest by capacity, Plaza de Toros is the largest ring in Spain, and possibly the world. Even if you disapprove of bullfighting this is a great tour for the history and the architecture.

frontmatter.title: Málaga Nostrum Commercial Park
frontmatter.description: Málaga Nostrum Commercial Park - Although this Málaga shopping centre is not located in the city centre, Málaga Nostrum is a great place for shopping enthusiasts. Pick up some bargains from the factory outlet with discounts up to 70% off brands such as Levi's, Mango, Desigual, Spagnolo, Fifty Factory and Mustang. In addition, there is an entertainment zone with a bowling alley and a multitude of restaurants.

node.html: Málaga Nostrum Commercial Park - Although this Málaga shopping centre is not located in the city centre, Málaga Nostrum is a great place for shopping enthusiasts. Pick up some bargains from the factory outlet with discounts up to 70% off brands such as Levi's, Mango, Desigual, Spagnolo, Fifty Factory and Mustang. In addition, there is an entertainment zone with a bowling alley and a multitude of restaurants.

frontmatter.title: Miramar Centro Comercial
frontmatter.description: Miramar Centro Comercial - The Miramar shopping centre has a large supermarket and a big variety of other shops, eateries and coffee shops. The center is easily accessible from Fuengirola by local buses 1 or 4. There is a taxi rank directly outside the entrance. The centre also features a cinema and go karting on the roof level. Car parking is available inside or outside free of charge. A few minutes walk away, across the foot bridge is an Iceland and many more shops and cafes as well as petrol station.

node.html: Miramar Centro Comercial - The Miramar shopping centre has a large supermarket and a big varity of other shops, eateries and coffee shops. frontmatter.title: Baby Cakes Marbella - Baby Bounce and Rhyme La Cala
frontmatter.description: Baby Cakes Marbella - Baby Bounce and Rhyme La Cala - Looking for something fun to do with your babies and toddlers? Baby Cakes Marbella run fun workshops for children from 0 to 4 years of age. These workshops are run at different venues and on different days all along the Costa del  Sol.

node.html: Looking for something fun to do with your babies and toddlers? Baby Cakes Marbella run fun workshops for children from 0 to 4 years of age. These workshops are run at different venues and on different days all along the Costa del Sol.

frontmatter.title: Real Club Valderrama
frontmatter.description: Real Club Valderrama - This is a private golf club which allows non-members every day from 10h00 to 12h00 to play its magnificent golf course. The course is maintained well and in perfect condition. There is a Club House with all the facilities you need, a well equipped pro shop and a restaurant with very good food and service.

node.html: This is a private golf club which allows non-members every day from 10h00 to 12h00 to play its magnificent golf course. The course is maintained well and in perfect condition. There is a Club House with all the facilities you need, a well equipped pro shop and a restaurant with very good food and service.

frontmatter.title: Ventura de Mar beach
frontmatter.description: Ventura de Mar beach - This beach has two designated dog-friendly zones. Dog owners are allowed to bring their pets without any time restrictions. Owners must be in full control of their dog at all times, carry proof of their dog’s vaccinations, respect other beach users and clean up any dog mess. The beach is not for swimming.

node.html: This beach has two designated dog-friendly zones. Dog owners are allowed to bring their pets without any time restrictions. Owners must be in full control of their dog at all times, carry proof of their dog’s vaccinations, respect other beach users and clean up any dog mess. The beach is not for swimming.

frontmatter.title: El Espigón beach
frontmatter.description: El Espigón beach  - Situated in Marismas de Odiel natural park, the canine zone extends from the 6th footbridge to the breakwater. The beach has fine sand but no services.

node.html: Situated in Marismas de Odiel natural park, the canine zone extends from the 6th footbridge to the breakwater. The beach has fine sand but no services.

frontmatter.title: Simply Diving Marbella
frontmatter.description: Simply Diving Marbella - A British-run PADI 5 Star Career Development and IDC Dive Centres in Spain. Catering for all scuba diving levels from beginner to advance. Sister schoolin Torremolinos.

node.html: A British-run PADI 5 Star Career Development and IDC Dive Centres in Spain. Catering for all scuba diving levels from beginner to advance. Sister schoolin Torremolinos.
